comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
The date 30 11 [November] 3? can be seen in reverse in the bottom left corner. The year must be 1939 (thank you beachcomberaustralia) based on articles in the Sydney Morning Herald re the demolition work and also the advertisement for the French film 'La Bandera' on the hoardings. 'La Bandera' ran from 25 November 1939 to 1 February 1940 at the New Savoy.
Work on demolishing the 1810 Commissariat Stores began on 5 July 1939. The protest letter to the editor of PC Mowle of Neutral Bay, published 2 November, comments that the demolition of the Commissariat building was complete and that windows and roof slates had been removed from the old Taxation Building. A further article published on 10 November states that the walls were being demolished. See Sydney Morning Herald 25 November 1939 p11, 27 January 1940 p10, 6 July 1939 pp8 and 10,  2 November 1939 p7, 10 November 1939 p6, and 27 November 1939 pp10 and 12.
JS

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [weeping for the loss of the Commissariat Stores] "La bandera' 1935 - www.imdb.com/title/tt0026095/

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia have you seen the Darling Harbour resumption maps held by State Records, NRS 19348, 1900-1902, in particular Plan U 'Map of Resumption Area bounded by Darling Harbour, George Street, Bethel Street, Circular Quay, Queens Wharf (Within section 83 and part of section 86)', 12 Jun 1902. I believe this is the same site. Go to Archives Investigator -> Advanced Search -> Record Series ->19348 and browse through the list "Record items in this series" until you find the link to Plan U. When you have the entry for Plan U, click on the link in the 'Images' field to bring up the image of the map. JS

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks JS - yes, I have seen those marvelous maps; they are full of fascinating detail, and help enormously with building and street identification.  But they are unusually difficult to find on the Archives site, and impossible to link to (no persistent URL), evidenced by your instructions above.  A couple are on your photostream at a lower resolution, and I refer to  them often.

I see from the relevant Plan U that the Commissariat Stores were under Military Lands control  until 1899, rather than the NSW State Government.  Great stuff!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The photo is taken from the Sydney Harbour Trust building. The new Maritime Services Board building had to be built on the Commissariat Stores site before the Sydney Harbour Trust building could be demolished, and the Circular Quay Railway constructed, albeit WWII delayed the timeframe. Queens Wharf was known as Barton Street at the time of this photo.
